response.answer_text: Auxiliary equation is [math]m^2–4=(m+2)(m-2)=0[/math] The roots are 2 and -2. The complimentary function is [math]y_c=C_1e^{2x}+C_2 e^{-2x}[/math] Particular integral [math]y_p=\dfrac {1}{D^2–4} x^2[/math] [math]=\dfrac {1}{-4(1-\frac {D^2}{4})} x^2[/math] [math]=\dfrac {(1-\frac {D^2}{4})^{-1}}{-4} x^2[/math] [math]=\dfrac {(1+\frac {D^2}{4}+\frac {D^4}{16}+….)^{-1}}{-4} x^2[/math] [math]=\dfrac {(x^2+\frac {2}{4}+0+….)}{-4} x^2[/math] [math]=-\dfrac {(2x^2+1)}{8}[/math] [math]y=y_c+y_p[/math] [math]=\boxed{C_1e^{2x}+C_2 e^{-2x}-\dfrac {(2x^2+1)}{8}}[/math]

This is a second-order linear ordinary differential equation with constant coefficients. Although this can be solved using a particular integral, the equation is simple enough that I would instead solve this using undetermined coefficients. We have [math]y'' - 4y = x^2.[/math] First solve the homogeneous equation [math]y'' - 4y = 0,[/math] the solutions of which can be obtained by finding the roots of the characteristic polynomial: [math]r^2 - 4 = 0[/math] [math]r = 2, -2[/math] The homogeneous solution is therefore [math]y_h = c_1 e^{2x} + c_2 e^{-2x}.[/math] Now, to find a particular solution of the original equation, use undetermined coefficients. Since the right-hand side is [math]x^2[/math], let [math]y = ax^2 + bx + c.[/math] Then [math]y' = 2ax + b[/math] and [math]y'' = 2a.[/math] Substituting this back into the equation gives [math]y'' - 4y = 2a - 4(ax^2 + bx + c) = -4ax^2 - 4bx + (2a - 4c) = x^2.[/math] Thus, [math]a = -\frac{1}{4}, b = 0, c = -\frac{1}{8},[/math] so a particular solution is given by [math]y_p = -\frac{x^2}{4} - \frac{1}{8} = -\frac{1}{8} (2x^2 + 1).[/math] The general solution of the differential equation is simply the sum of a particular solution and the homogeneous solution, so [math]y = c_1 e^{2x} + c_2 e^{-2x} - \frac{1}{8} (2x^2 + 1).[/math]
